title: How does Pauli exclusion principle work? - Quora

response.answer_text: Essentially, the Pauli exclusion principle is generally relevant when you have a bound, energy-minimizing systems.* The “bound” requirement means that there has to be some sort of interaction, although it could be an interaction with an external potential (supplied by, say, a proton). The “energy-minimizing” means that we’re not really looking at a dynamical system like scattering, but rather an (approximately) equilibrium situation like an atom or a neutron star (and that’s a part of why we want a bound system). In other words: the PEP doesn’t come into play when they get close to each other. Rather it comes into play when it is pushed together and forced to do what it does when it is held there. What this tells you is that, for the potential emerging from this “pushing force,” instead of them both falling into the lowest energy state, due to the PEP, one will be forced up into the second-lowest energy state [or more properly the pair will be forced into an antisymmetric combination of those states]. *If you’re doing calculations of other systems in sufficient detail that something like PEP becomes relevant, then you’ probably need to understand more than Pauli exclusion to do computations, something like QFT - but that’s a separate matter, and beyond the scope of this answer.
